unnormalised: I've been working in the healthcare sector in India for over 15 years, and the way we manage numbers in medical records is still, honestly, a bit of a mess. I see so many problems that can easily be addressed with better data standardization.
normalised: I have been working in the healthcare sector in India for over fifteen years, and the way we manage numbers in medical records is still, honestly, a bit of a mess. I see so many problems that can easily be addressed with better data standardization.

unnormalised: First off, let’s talk about dates. A patient's date of birth might be recorded as 23/07/1988 in one place and 07/23/1988 in another. And for some older records, you might even find 23-July-88. Imagine the confusion when tracking medical history, especially if the patient is elderly and there's a need to cross-reference multiple records created over decades! It's a nightmare for the doctors and nurses trying to get a clear picture of a patient’s health trajectory. I know of at least 3 instances in the past year, in my own network of doctors, where the wrong dosage was prescribed because of this confusion.
normalised: First off, let’s talk about dates. And for some older records, you might even find twenty third july eighty eight. Imagine the confusion when tracking medical history, especially if the patient is elderly and there's a need to cross-reference multiple records created over decades! It's a nightmare for the doctors and nurses trying to get a clear picture of a patient’s health trajectory. I know of at least three instances in the past year, in my own network of doctors, where the wrong dosage was prescribed because of this confusion.

unnormalised: Then there’s the issue of phone numbers. Some records have the ISD code, others don’t. You might find +919876543210 in one file and simply 9876543210 in another. And then there are the handwritten records where the numbers are smudged, and you can't tell if it's a 3 or an 8. It’s a simple thing, but if the hospital needs to reach a patient urgently, these discrepancies can cause serious delays. We had a case where the patient wasn't informed about a critical test report for over a week simply because we couldn't reach them.

unnormalised: Age is another problem area. While most modern records will list the DOB and automatically calculate age, many older reports simply list the age at the time of the examination e.g "Patient aged 62 years". This creates extra steps when a complete history is needed. In some rare instances even height is listed as "5 ft 6 inch" instead of metric measures.
normalised: Age is another problem area. While most modern records will list the D-O-B and automatically calculate age, many older reports simply list the age at the time of the examination e.g. "Patient aged sixty two years". This creates extra steps when a complete history is needed. In some rare instances even height is listed as "five feet six inch" instead of metric measures.

unnormalised: Numeric data related to patient vitals is also inconsistent. Blood pressure might be recorded as 120/80 mmHg in some reports, while others might just say 120/80. Blood sugar levels could be in mg/dL or mmol/L, and sometimes it's not even specified, and doctors are left guessing and converting. Same goes for dosages. Dr. Sharma might write "Paracetamol 500mg" on his prescription while Dr. Rao writes "Paracetamol 0.5g". You need special training to catch these inconsistencies. This is a HUGE safety issue!
normalised: Numeric data related to patient vitals is also inconsistent. Blood pressure might be recorded as one hundred and twenty divided by eighty millimeter of mercury in some reports, while others might just say one hundred and twenty divided by eighty. Blood sugar levels could be in milligram per deciliter or millimole per liter, and sometimes it's not even specified, and doctors are left guessing and converting. Same goes for dosages. Doctor Sharma might write "Paracetamol five hundred milligram" on his prescription while Doctor Rao writes "Paracetamol zero point five gram". You need special training to catch these inconsistencies. This is a H-U-G-E safety issue!

unnormalised: And let’s not forget the financial aspect. In billing, prices are often recorded with inconsistent currency symbols. You might see "Rs 5000", "₹5000", or even just "5000 INR", creating headaches for the accounts department and patients trying to understand their bills. It is a problem for insurance companies as well, when they need to audit bills.
normalised: And let’s not forget the financial aspect. In billing, prices are often recorded with inconsistent currency symbols. You might see "rupees five thousand", "rupee five thousand", or even just "five thousand I-N-R", creating headaches for the accounts department and patients trying to understand their bills. It is a problem for insurance companies as well, when they need to audit bills.

unnormalised: The solution? Standardized digital record-keeping. Every hospital and clinic should adopt a uniform format for dates (YYYY-MM-DD), phone numbers (+91 followed by the 10-digit number), vitals (using universally recognized units), and currency (INR). And while digitizing, a careful effort is needed to ensure older handwritten records are properly converted. The Indian Medical Association (IMA) needs to take the lead and set the standard, and the government should incentivize hospitals to adopt these best practices.
normalised: The solution? Standardized digital record-keeping. Every hospital and clinic should adopt a uniform format for dates (Y-Y-Y-Y dash M-M dash D-D), phone numbers (plus nine one followed by the ten-digit number), vitals (using universally recognized units), and currency (I-N-R). And while digitizing, a careful effort is needed to ensure older handwritten records are properly converted. The Indian Medical Association (I-M-A) needs to take the lead and set the standard, and the government should incentivize hospitals to adopt these best practices.

unnormalised: This is not just about efficiency; it's about patient safety. Standardizing these numbers will reduce errors, improve communication, and ultimately save lives. Because when it comes to healthcare, every number matters.
